children.name: I: Exploring Data
children.tagline: Describing patterns and departures from patterns
children.description: Exploratory analysis of data makes use of graphical and numerical techniques to study patterns and departures from patterns. Emphasis should be placed on interpreting information from graphical and numerical displays and summaries.

children.name: A
children.tagline: Constructing and interpreting graphical displays of distributions of univariate data

children.name: 1-A-1
children.tagline: Understanding dotplot

children.name: 1-A-2
children.tagline: Understanding stemplot

children.name: 1-A-3
children.tagline: Understanding histogram

children.name: 1-A-4
children.tagline: Understanding cumulative frequency plot

children.name: 1-A-5
children.tagline: Locating Center from a graph

children.name: 1-A-6
children.tagline: Locating Spread from a graph

children.name: 1-A-7
children.tagline: Identifying (a)symmetry of graph

children.name: 1-A-8
children.tagline: Identifying modality of graph

children.name: 1-A-9
children.tagline: Identifying a point from a graph using scales and labels

children.name: 1-A-10
children.tagline: Identifying outliers visually from graph

children.name: B
children.tagline: Summarizing distributions of univariate data

children.name: 1-B-1
children.tagline: Calculating median

children.name: 1-B-2
children.tagline: Calculating mean

children.name: 1-B-3
children.tagline: Knowing the appropriate context to use median over mean or vice versa

children.name: 1-B-4
children.tagline: Calculating range

children.name: 1-B-5
children.tagline: Calculating interquartile range (IQR)

children.name: 1-B-6
children.tagline: Calculating variance

children.name: 1-B-7
children.tagline: Calculating standard deviation

children.name: 1-B-8
children.tagline: Recognizing difference between sample and population standard deviation

children.name: 1-B-9
children.tagline: Knowing appropriate context to use IQR over standard deviation

children.name: 1-B-10
children.tagline: Calculating z-scoregiven a raw score, and the mean and sd (from X to z)

children.name: 1-B-11
children.tagline: Interpret z-scores (#sds above/below mean)

children.name: 1-B-12
children.tagline: Calculating quartiles

children.name: 1-B-13
children.tagline: Interpreting percentiles

children.name: 1-B-14
children.tagline: Comparing positions within data (percentile, quantile, standard scores)

children.name: 1-B-15
children.tagline: Determining effect of changing units on summary statistics

children.name: 1-B-16
children.tagline: Identifying a correct boxplot

children.name: 1-B-17
children.tagline: Interpreting values within a boxplot

children.name: 1-B-18
children.tagline: Calculating outliers using fences

children.tagline: Comparing distributions of univariate data (dotplots, back-to-back stemplots, parallel boxplots)

children.tagline: Comparing and interpreting centers

children.name: 1-C-2
children.tagline: Comparing and interpreting spreads

children.name: 1-C-3
children.tagline: Comparing and interpreting shapes

children.name: 1-C-4
children.tagline: Comparing and interpreting clusters/gaps

children.name: 1-C-5
children.tagline: Comparing and interpreting outliers

children.name: D
children.tagline: Exploring bivariate data

children.name: 1-D-1
children.tagline: Identifying shape, direction, strength of a Scatterplot

children.name: 1-D-2
children.tagline: Knowing properties of a Correlation coefficient

children.name: 1-D-3
children.tagline: Interpreting coefficient of determination: R square

children.name: 1-D-4
children.tagline: Writing Least Squares Regression Line (LSRL)from computer output

children.name: 1-D-5
children.tagline: Obtaining LSRL from dataset

children.name: 1-D-6
children.tagline: Writing LSRL from summary statistics (using b1=r*(sy/sx) formula) (not likely)

children.name: 1-D-7
children.tagline: Interpreting slope

children.name: 1-D-8
children.tagline: Interpreting intercept

children.name: 1-D-9
children.tagline: Finding a predicted y-hator based on y-hat to find x given the regression equation

children.name: 1-D-10
children.tagline: Finding a residual value given the regression equation

children.name: 1-D-11
children.tagline: Interpreting a residual

children.name: 1-D-12
children.tagline: Using residual plot to determine if transformation is needed, i.e., is linear model appropriate

children.name: 1-D-13
children.tagline: Understanding lower reliability in extrapolation

children.name: 1-D-14
children.tagline: Identifying influential points and their impact on model (leverage)

children.name: 1-D-15
children.tagline: Identifying correct re-expression (log, power, exponential)

children.name: 1-D-16
children.tagline: Correctly calculating a predicted value under a transformation (log/power/exponential)

children.name: E
children.tagline: Exploring categorical data

children.name: 1-E-1
children.tagline: Knowing the Difference between categorical and quantitative variables

children.name: II: Sampling and Experimentation
children.tagline: Planning and conducting a study
children.description: Data must be collected according to a well-developed plan if valid information on a conjecture is to be obtained. This plan includes clarifying the question and deciding upon a method of data collection and analysis.

children.name: A
children.tagline: Exploring categorical data

children.name: 2-A-1
children.tagline: Knowing census is a collection of info. from the entire population

children.name: 2-A-2
children.tagline: Knowing the distinction between experimental and observational study

children.name: B
children.tagline: Planning and conducting surveys

children.name: 2-B-1
children.tagline: Knowing a well conducted and designed survey must be random

children.name: 2-B-2
children.tagline: Knowing a well conducted and designed survey must minimize bias

children.name: 2-B-3
children.tagline: Knowing the population of interest for a sample survey

children.name: 2-B-4
children.tagline: Distinguishingbetween population parameter and sample statistics

children.name: 2-B-5
children.tagline: Identifying a sample was collected randomly (addresses when sample collected with voluntary or convenience)

children.name: 2-B-6
children.tagline: Understanding what a response and nonresponse bias is

children.name: 2-B-7
children.tagline: Identifying when a sample is collected using a simple random sample

children.name: 2-B-8
children.tagline: Identifying when a sample is collected using stratified random sample

children.name: 2-B-9
children.tagline: Identifying when a sample is collected using cluster random sample

children.name: C
children.tagline: Planning and conducting experiments

children.name: 2-C-1
children.tagline: Knowing in an experiment that treatments are assigned randomly

children.name: 2-C-2
children.tagline: Knowing in an experiment that treatments are replicated to many subjects/experimental units

children.name: 2-C-3
children.tagline: Understanding the benefit for a control group

children.name: 2-C-4
children.tagline: Identifying # of treatments from a multi-factor experiment (in curriculum?)

children.name: 2-C-5
children.tagline: Identifying the experimental units in an experiment

children.name: 2-C-6
children.tagline: Knowing to control variables that are not a factor of an experiment (in curriculum?)

children.name: 2-C-7
children.tagline: Knowing the purpose of random assignment in experiments

children.name: 2-C-8
children.tagline: Understanding the difference between none, single and doubleblinded experiments

children.name: 2-C-9
children.tagline: Understanding that blinding helps prevent bias in experiment

children.name: 2-C-10
children.tagline: Understanding the purpose of blocking in an experiment

children.name: 2-C-11
children.tagline: Identifying between completely randomized and randomized block design

children.name: 2-C-12
children.tagline: Identifying a matched pairs design

children.name: D
children.tagline: Generalizability of results and types of conclusions that can be drawn from observational studies, experiments and surveys

children.name: 2-D-1
children.tagline: Knowing experimental studies can show causation whereas observational studies do not

children.name: 2-D-2
children.tagline: Knowing experimental results can only be generalized to those represented by the experimental units

children.name: E
children.tagline: Miscellaneous

children.name: 2-E-1
children.tagline: When to use stratified vs. cluster sampling (homogeneous groups vs heterogeneous groups)

children.name: 2-E-2
children.tagline: Random sampling variability

children.name: 2-E-3
children.tagline: Identifying confounding variables

children.name: III: Anticipating Patterns
children.tagline: Exploring random phenomena using probability and simulation
children.description: Probability is the tool used for anticipating what the distribution of data should look like under a given model.

children.name: A
children.tagline: Probability

children.name: 3-A-1
children.tagline: Interpreting probability as a long-run relative frequency interpretation

children.name: 3-A-2
children.tagline: Understanding the Law of Large Numbers

children.name: 3-A-3
children.tagline: Understanding and correctly applying the Addition Rule

children.name: 3-A-4
children.tagline: Understanding and correctly applying the Multiplication Rule

children.name: 3-A-5
children.tagline: Calculating conditional probability

children.name: 3-A-6
children.tagline: Recognizing independent events

children.name: 3-A-7
children.tagline: Recognizing disjoint (mutually exclusive) events

children.name: 3-A-8
children.tagline: Distinguishing between discrete and continuous random variables

children.name: 3-A-9
children.tagline: Recognizing a binomial random variable

children.name: 3-A-10
children.tagline: Computing a binomial probability

children.name: 3-A-11
children.tagline: Recognizing a geometric random variable

children.name: 3-A-12
children.tagline: Computing a geometric probability

children.name: 3-A-13
children.tagline: Computing cumulative probability of a discrete random variable

children.name: 3-A-14
children.tagline: Interpreting a simulation of random behavior or a simulated probability distribution

children.name: 3-A-15
children.tagline: Calculating the mean (expected value) of a discrete random variable

children.name: 3-A-16
children.tagline: Calculating the standard deviation of a discrete random variable

children.name: 3-A-17
children.tagline: Understanding the effects of a linear transformation on a random variable (i.e. on the measures of center and spread)

children.name: 3-A-18
children.tagline: Using common structures to analyze probability problems (Venn diagram, tree, table)

children.name: B
children.tagline: Combining independent random variables

children.name: 3-B-1
children.tagline: Distinguishing between independent and dependent events

children.name: 3-B-2
children.tagline: Calculating the mean for the sum or the difference of independent random variables

children.name: 3-B-3
children.tagline: Calculating the standard deviation for the sum or the difference of independent random variables

children.name: C
children.tagline: The normal distribution

children.name: 3-C-1
children.tagline: Understanding the characteristics of the normal distribution (symmetric, 68-95-99.7 rule, unimodal, etc.)

children.name: 3-C-2
children.tagline: Calculating a probability using the z-score and the standard normal distribution (e.g., normcdf)

children.name: 3-C-3
children.tagline: Calculating a z-score using probabilities on a normal distribution(e.g., norminv)

children.name: 3-C-4
children.tagline: Calculating the raw-score given a z-score (from z to X)

children.name: 3-C-5
children.tagline: Using the normal distribution to model and calculate measurements from a contextual application

children.name: D
children.tagline: Sampling distributions

children.name: 3-D-1
children.tagline: Interpreting the concept of a sampling distribution

children.name: 3-D-2
children.tagline: Describing the sampling distribution of a sample proportion (shape, center, spread)

children.name: 3-D-3
children.tagline: Describing the sampling distribution of a sample mean (shape, center, spread)

children.name: 3-D-4
children.tagline: Applying the Central Limit Theorem

children.name: 3-D-5
children.tagline: Describing the sampling distribution of the difference between two independent sample proportions (shape, center, spread)

children.name: 3-D-6
children.tagline: Describing the sampling distribution of the difference between two independent sample means (shape, center, spread)

children.name: 3-D-7
children.tagline: Interpreting a simulation of a sampling distribution

children.name: 3-D-8
children.tagline: Understanding characteristics of a t-distribution

children.name: 3-D-9
children.tagline: Using the t-distribution to calculate a probability

children.name: 3-D-10
children.tagline: Using the t-distribution to obtain a t score (critical value)

children.name: 3-D-11
children.tagline: Understanding the differences between a t-distribution and a normal distribution

children.name: 3-D-12
children.tagline: Understanding the characteristics of the chi-square distribution

children.name: 3-D-13
children.tagline: Using the chi-square to calculate a probability

children.name: 3-D-14
children.tagline: Using the chi-square distribution to obtain a critical value

children.name: IV: Statistical Inference
children.tagline: Estimating population parameters and testing hypotheses
children.description: Statistical inference guides the selection of appropriate models.

children.name: A
children.tagline: Estimation (point estimators and confidence intervals)

children.name: 4-A-1
children.tagline: Margins of error vs standard error

children.name: 4-A-2
children.tagline: Margin of error/interval length, i.e., interaction with sample size and/or level of confidence

children.name: 4-A-3
children.tagline: Logic of confidence intervals

children.name: 4-A-4
children.tagline: Interpreting confidence level

children.name: 4-A-5
children.tagline: Computing Large sample confidence interval for a proportion

children.name: 4-A-6
children.tagline: Computing Large sample confidence interval for a difference between two proportions

children.name: 4-A-7
children.tagline: Computing Confidence interval for a mean

children.name: 4-A-8
children.tagline: Computing Confidence interval for a difference between two means: unpaired

children.name: 4-A-9
children.tagline: Computing Confidence interval for a difference between two means: paired

children.name: 4-A-10
children.tagline: Computing Confidence interval for the slope of a least-squares regression line

children.name: B
children.tagline: Tests of significance

children.name: 4-B-1
children.tagline: Logic of significance testing, null and alternative hypotheses

children.name: 4-B-2
children.tagline: Concept of p-values (e.g., using NORMCDF given a critical value)

children.name: 4-B-3
children.tagline: Interpretation of a p-value (e.g., percentage of times the sample result will occur if the null is true)

children.name: 4-B-4
children.tagline: Understanding/Comparing one-and two-sided tests

children.name: 4-B-5
children.tagline: Concepts of Type I error

children.name: 4-B-6
children.tagline: Concept of Type II errors

children.name: 4-B-7
children.tagline: Concept of power

children.name: 4-B-8
children.tagline: Relationship among type-I and type-II errors and power

children.name: 4-B-9
children.tagline: Effect of changing sample size on type II error, power for fixed level of significance

children.name: 4-B-10
children.tagline: Conditions for inference for a proportion

children.name: 4-B-11
children.tagline: Performing Large sample test for a proportion

children.name: 4-B-12
children.tagline: Conditions for inference for difference in two proportions

children.name: 4-B-13
children.tagline: Performing Large sample test for a difference between two proportions

children.name: 4-B-14
children.tagline: Conditions for inference for a mean

children.name: 4-B-15
children.tagline: Performing Test for a mean

children.name: 4-B-16
children.tagline: Conditions for inference for a difference between two means

children.name: 4-B-17
children.tagline: Performing test for a difference between two means: unpaired (t-test)

children.name: 4-B-18
children.tagline: Performing Test for a difference between two means: paired (t-test)

children.name: 4-B-19
children.tagline: Conditions for Chi-square test

children.name: 4-B-20
children.tagline: Performing Chi-square test for goodness of fit

children.name: 4-B-21
children.tagline: Performing Chi-square test for homogeneity of proportions

children.name: 4-B-22
children.tagline: Performing Chi-square test for independence (two-way tables)

children.name: 4-B-23
children.tagline: Performing Test for the slope of a least-squares regression line

children.name: 4-B-24
children.tagline: Parallel between 2-sided test and confidence interval for the means

children.name: 4-B-25
children.tagline: Making decision/conclusion by comparing p-value and alpha
